titlestmt.title: SSSC 01:The Birth of Wisahketchahk and the Origin of Mankind
titlestmt.author: Louis Moosomin

bibl.title: Sacred Stories of the Sweet Grass Cree
bibl.series: National Museum of Canada, Bulletin no. 60, Anthropological Series, no. 11

encodingdesc.p: This electronic document is oriented more toward representing those features that seem most likely to be relevant for grammatical analyses, rather than toward faithfully representing all the information available in the book.

list.item: 2014 06 10; KR; UTF-8, paragraph and sentence numbering, smart-quotes in English translations

body.head: Sacred Stories 01: The Birth of Wisahketchahk and the Origin of Mankind

p.seg: kayâs kîtahtawê -- êkwah nitâtayôhkân -- kîtahtawê yâhkih pêyak nâpêw pêyakokamikisiw , wîwa êkwah nîs ôtawâsimisah . Once upon a time, long ago -- I am now telling a sacred story -- once upon a time, of old, a certain man dwelt in a lone lodge with his wife and his two children.
kîtahtawê mâna sêpwêhtêci , owîkimâkana wawêsiyiwa . Then presently, whenever he went away, his wife put on her finery.
namoya kiskêyihtam tanêhk ôhci êh-wawêsiyit owîkimâkana . He did not know why his wife put on her finery.
kîtahtawê kontah sipwêhtêhkâsôw , êh-mâcît ; So then at one time he merely pretended to go away to hunt;

êkwah kâsôw ,
mahtih kê-tôtahk , êh-itêyimât . he hid himself, thinking of her, “let me see what she will do.”

pôti êkwah kâ-wâpamât mistikwah êh-pah-pakamahwâyit , êkwah ka-pê-wayawiyit kinêpikwa , kâ-wâpamât owîkimâkana êh-owîcimosiyit , sêmâk mistahi kisiwâsiw . And then he saw her beating a tree, and a serpent came out, and he saw that his wife had it for a lover, at once he was very angry.

mistikwah êh-pakamahwâyit wîwa ,
ninâpêm , êkwah nitakohtân ! itwêyiwa . When his wife struck the tree, she said, “My husband, now I have come!”
kisiwâsiw mistahi . He was very angry.
ohtêyihtam ; ayisk osâm nawac sâkihimâwa kinêpikwa . He was jealous; for the serpent was loved more than he.
êyakonih ôhi kâ-wi-âtayôhkâtimak wîsâhkêcâhk okâwiyah mîn ôhtâwiyah . Those of whom I mean to tell the sacred story were Wisahketchahk's mother and father.
êkwah awa nâpêw mistahi kisiwâsiw ; nama kîh-nipâw . So now that man was very angry; he could not sleep.

ômis îtêw wîwa :
wâhyaw niwîh-isi-mâcîn , itêw wîwa . He said to his wife: “I am going far away to hunt.”
tâpwê mitoni wâhyaw isi mâcîw . He really went very far away to hunt.
pêyakotipiskwêw . He stayed over one night.
tânêhki k-ôh-katikoniyan ? itik owîkimâkana . “Why did you stay out over night?” his wife asked him.
mâka kiya kika-nâtên wiyâsah , itêw wîwa . “But you, are to fetch the meat,” he told his wife.
êhag , itwêw âw îskwêw . “Very well,” said she.
mayaw ê-sipwêhtêyit wîwa , oskotâkayiw otinam , êh-postiskahk . As soon as his wife had gone, he took her skirt and put it on.
itohtêw ôhi kinêpikwah itah k-âsiwasoyit mistikohk . He went to where that serpent was inside the tree.
ninâpêm , nitakohtân ! itêw kinêpikwah . “My husband, I have come!” he said to the serpent.
tâpwêh pê-wayawiyiwa . Really, it came out.
mîcimâpoy osîhtâw . he made a broth.
êkwah kâtêw otawâsimisah . Then he hid his children.
cikêmâ maywês askiy ihtakohk , nanâtohk isi kîsi-kaskihtâwak . One must keep in mind that before the earth existed they had many kinds of power.
kâh-kotâwinêw otawâsimisah askîhk . He plunged his two children into the ground.

êkwah awah iskwêw mistahi kahkiyaw kêkway kaskihtâw , ahpôh kahkiyaw kêkway êsah êh-pîkiskwâtahk , êkosi êsa ê-naskowasimikot . And that woman, too, had great power for all things, and could talk even to every kind of thing and accordingly receive answer from it.
êkwah kahkiyaw kêkway mîna nâpêw pîhcâyihk ôtah k-êhtakoniyik kitahamawêw êkâ kêkway kita-wîhtamâkoyit . And then the man forbade every object that was in their dwelling to tell her anything.
takohtêyiwa êkwah wîwa . Then his wife arrived.
asamêw kinêpikwa kâ-kîh-mîcimâpôhkâkêt . He gave her the serpent to eat which he had cooked into broth.

hwah , kêkway ôma , itwêw aw îskwêw ,
mistahih kâ-wîhkasik ? “Oh, what is this,” asked the woman, “which tastes so good?”
kinâpêm kinêpik omihkoh , êkotôwahk ohcih kâ-osîhtamâtân , itêw . “The blood of your husband, the serpent; from it I have made this for you,” he told her.
kisiwâsiw aw îskwêw . The woman was angry.
nama cî tâpwê ahpôh êkos êh-tôtaman ? itêw êsah . “It is not true, is it, that you have done even this?” she asked him.
itohtêw itêh mâna kinêpikwah kâ-ntawâpamât aw îskwêw . So she went to where she was in the habit of visiting the serpent.
êkwah pakamahwêw mistikwah . Then she struck the tree.
namwâc kinêpikwah pê-wayawiyiwa . The serpent did not come out.
mistahi kisiwâsiw , kont êh-pê-mawihkâtât . She was very angry, as she came back, loudly bewailing it.
êh-pê-pîhtokêt , onâpêma kîskikwêtahok . When she entered the dwelling, her husband cut off her head.
êkos îs ôhpiskâw awa nâpêw , êh-tapasît . Then he rose into the air, to flee.

seg.gloss: “I shall needs go dwell there in the sky.

p.seg: nikah-acahkosiwin ! itwêw , êh-at-îsi-ohpiskât . Let me be a star!” he said, as he rose higher and higher.
êkwah awa iskwêw , kîtahtawê tôhkâpîmakan ômah pisisik mistikwânis . And that woman, that severed head presently opened its eyes.
êkwah kîtahtawê kâ-pîkiskwêt om ôstikwân . Then presently that head spoke.
sôskwâc kahkiyaw kakwêcimêw otâpacihcikanah . Without delay, she asked all her utensils.
kahkiyaw mitonih kâh-kitôtam , êh-kakwêcihtahk . She spoke to every single one in turn, questioning it.
pôtih asiniya kâ-wîhtamâkot askîhk êh-kîh-kotâwinâyit onâpêma . At last a stone told her that her husband had sunk them into the earth.

nêo kêkway kîh-miyêw otawâsimisah awa nâpêw , ispîhk ê-sipwêtisahwât , sîpiy kit-ôsîhtâyit , êkwah iskotêw , êkwah asinîwaciy , êkwah sakâw , okâminakasîwi-sakâw . Four things that man had given his children, at the time when he started them off; that they might make a river, fire, a mountain of stone, and a forest; a forest of thorn trees.
êkwah têpwêw awa ostikwânis awa . Then that head began to call.
kikitimahinâwâw kâ-nakasiyêk ! itwêw . You are making me wretched by leaving me!” it cried.
tahkih têpwêw awa iskwêw . That woman called all the time.

êkwah awa nâpêsis itâmaskamik kây-isih-tapasît , wâhyaw ohcih wâpahtam ôma pisisik mistikwân êh-pîkiskwêmakaniyik , êh-nayômikot ostêsêh . And that little boy who was fleeing under ground, from afar he saw that severed speaking head, as he was being carried on his elder brother's back.

ômis îtaw :
nistêsê , nama kêkway kikâwiyinaw . He said to him, “Big brother, our mother is not there.
ostikwân pikoh kâ-pîkiskwêmakahk , itwêw . It is only a talking head,” he said.

otinêw ôhtâwiyah kâ-kîh-miyikot , iskotêw nêhiyawak k-ôh-ôsîhtâcik ; wêpinêw nâway isi . He took that which his father had given him, that from which the Cree make fire; he threw it behind him. LB's footnote to {k-ôh-ôsîhtâcik}: Word avoided, probably {posâkan}: “birch-fungus, used as tinder.”
ôtah iskotêw ta-wîh-ayâw ! itwêw . “Let there be fire!” he said.
tâpwêh mistahi nakânikôw awa , wâhyaw ohcih iskotêw êy-isih-kwâhkotêyik . And really that being was entirely brought to a stop, when far and wide the fire blazed.
ayis pisisik ostikwân pimohtêmakaniyiw . For it was but a severed head which went along.

êwako pikoh nêhiyaw kâh-isiyîhkâsot êsah mac-âyisah ê-kîh-wîcihikot , pisisik ostikwân k-ô-tihtipipayiyik . Because he, at any rate, who is called Indian was helped by evil beings, was why that severed head could roll along.
piyisk miyâskam iskotêw . Finally it passed by the fire.
êkwah nawaswâtêw sâsay mîna otawâsimisah . Then it again pursued its children.
kahkiyaw saskitêyiwah wêstakayah . All its hair was aflame.

êkwah minah kîtahtawê êh-ay-itâpit ana kâ-nayômiht awâsis ,
namoya kikâwînaw , nistêsê ! kiyâm sôhkih tapasîtân ! itêw . Then presently when again that child looked about, who was being borne by the other, “It is not our mother, big brother! Let us flee with all our might!” he told him.
âsay mîna kîhtwâm otinam ôhtâwiyah kâ-kîh-miyikot ôkaminakasiyiwaciy kit-ôsîhtât . Again he took that which his father had given him that he might make a hill of thornberry-trees.
nâway isiwêpinêw . He threw it behind him.
tâpwêh âcisin aw ostikwân kâ-tihtipipayiyit . That Rolling Skull was really blocked.

êkwah atotêw misi-kinêpikwah , kita-kâh-kîskamâyit okâminakasiya , kita-tawinamâkot , sôskwâc kita-pimohtêt . Then it bade a Great Serpent to bite through the thorn-trees and make a passage through for it, that it might go unchecked.
tâpwê kaskihôw sôskwâc êh-pimohtêt . And so it managed to go on, unchecked.

êkwah âsay mîna wâhyaw êh-itâmocik , âsay mîna pêtisâpamêw ostikwân êh-pê-tihtipipayiyit awa awâsis kâ-nayômiht . Then, when again they had fled a long ways, again that child who was being carried saw the Skull come rolling.

âsay mina kâ-kîh-miyikot ôhtâwiyah asinîwaciy kitâ-ôsihtât âsay mîna nâway isiwêpinam . And again, he threw behind them that which he had been given by his father that he might make a mountain of rock.
mistahi mis-îspayiw asinîwaciy . Vastly that rock crag extended.
nama kîh-kaskihôw awa ostikwânis ta-pâsitohtêt . That Skull-Being could not manage to go across it.
kwayask atotêw amiskwah ta-pîkwamâyit ôhi asiniya , êh-pîwâpiskôwiyikih wîpitiyiwa . At once it employed a beaver with iron teeth to bite the rock into pieces.
êkwah kaskihôw sâsay mîna . Then it was able to go on.
âsay mîna nawaswâtêw otawâsimisah . Again it pursued its children.
âsay mina pêtisâpamêw aw âwâsis kâ-nayômikot ostêsah . Again that child who was being borne by his elder brother saw it coming.
êkwah mîna sîpiy kit-ôh-ôsihtât kâ-kîh-miyikot ôhtâwiya ôtêh nîkân piscih isiwêpinam . Then that which his father had given him that he might make a river, he threw it, by mistake, on ahead.
at-îtwêw aw âwâsis . The child kept crying its cry.
mâtôwak êkwah , êh-kostahkik ta-nipahikocik ôma mistikwân ka-tihtipipayiyik , okâwîwâwa ostikwâniyiw . Then they wept in terror that the Rolling Skull would kill them, their mother's skull.

êkwah êh-mâtocik ,
êkâya mâtok ! kika-pihkohitinâwâw ! itikwak misi-kinêpikwah . Then as they wept, “Do not weep! I will take you to safety!” a Great Serpent said to them.
êkwah âsiwawihikok . Then he carried them across the water. LB: Probably for {âsiwakoyikok}.
êkwah akâmihk ê-kih-takohtahikocik , kâwih âsiwaham awa kâ-kiy-âsiwawahât ôhi awâsisah . When he had brought them to the far shore, he crossed back, who had taken the children across.

êh-wâpamât êkotê awa mistikwân kâ-tihtipipayit , ômis îtwêw :
âsiwawahin niya mîna ! itêw . When the Rolling Skull saw him, it said, “Take me across, too!” it said to him.
êkâya mâka papâsêyihtah , itik . “But do not be impatient” he told it.
tâpwê asiwahohik . So he carried it across.
pôsiw ospiskwaniyihk . It rode on his back.

mwêhcih tâwayihk nipîhk êh-ayâcik ,
misi-kinêpik , wêsâ kipêsiskân ! itwêw aw îskwêw . Just when they were in the middle of the stream, “Great Serpent, you are going all together too slowly!” said that woman.
êkwah pakastawêhok . Then he threw her into the water.

namêw
kik-êsiyîhkâson ! itik awa ostikwân awa kâ-tihtipipayit . “‘Sturgeon’ will be your name!” he told that Rolling Head.
êkwah ôki nâpêsisak papâmâcihowak , mistah ê-kwâtakihtâcik . Then those boys wandered about, suffering many hardships.
êwakw âwa otawâsisiwihtay wîsahkêcâhk . That boy was Wisahketchahk in his childhood.
êkospîhk êkwah sipwêhtêwak , osîmisah êh-wîcêwât . Then they departed from there, he with his little brother.
pâkahatôwânisah osîhtamawêw , ta-mêtawâkêyit . He made a ball for him to play with.

kîtahtawê cîkih sîpîhk êh-pa-pimohtêcik , êwako ostêsimâs ,
âstam ! k-êtikot kisêyiniwa otôsiyihk êh-pôsiyit . Then at one time, as they were walking by the river, the elder boy was told, “Come here!” by an old man in a canoe.
êh-pôsit , êkos îsi isi-kwâsihik . When he stepped into the canoe, this person carried him off.
êkwah awa k-âpisîsisit awa nakatik . They left the smaller boy behind.

êh-ât-îsi-mâtot ,
nistêsê , ntawâc niya nka-mahîhkaniwin ! itwêw awa nâpêsis osimimâs . Then as he began to weep, “Big brother, now I shall have to turn into a wolf!” cried that little boy, the younger one.
êkosi êwako pikoh kîh-otinâw wîsahkêcâhk , êkwah êkotê wîkiyihk êh-takohtahikot ôhi kisêyiniwa . Thus only Wisahketchahk was taken, and the old man brought him over yonder to his dwelling.
namoya ahpôh wîh-kîwêhtayik . he did not even care to take him home.
takohtêw wîkiwâhk awa kisêyiniw , nîso otânisa . The old man went to his abode, to his two daughters.
ntawâsimisitik , nipêsiwâw kit-siw-onâpêmiyêk , itwêw êsa ; “My children, I have brought someone for you to marry,” he said;
ntawâpamihk , itwêw . “Go look at him,” he said.
wayawîw êh-omisimâwit , êh-ntawâpamât . The older girl went out of the tent and looked at him.
mistah êcik âwa êh-mâyâtisiyit . Why he was very ugly!
namoya ta-kîh-onâpêmiyân awâsis ! itêw . “I cannot marry a child!” she said of him.
mâskôc ahpôh osâm mistah êh-mâtot , itwêw êsah . Perhaps it is only because he has been weeping too much,” he said.
êkwah itohtêw osîmimâw . Then the younger sister went there.
awa oskinîkiskwêw kîwêhtahêw anihih awâsisah , ê-kîh-kâsîhkwênât . This young woman brought the lad home, after washing his face.
pamihêw ; tâpwê onâpêmiw êwako . She took care of him; she really took him for her husband.

êkwah pakwâtêw awa omisimâw , wâwâc mâna ohcitaw êh-tôtahk awa awâsis , êh-mîsît otanâskâniyihk . The elder sister disliked him, and all the more so as the child wantonly played tricks, [no translation]

ê-kîh-nêwo-tipiskâyik mâka ômis îtêw :
mahtih matôtisânihkêh ; nik-ôsîhtân niyaw , itwêw . On the fourth night, however, he said to them, “Do you build a lodge for the steam-bath; I shall make my body,” he said.
tâpwê matôtisânihkêwân , êw-osîhtât wiyaw . Accordingly a sweat lodge was built for him, and he made his body.
êkwa mistahi miyosiw êh-âhciyisot . Then he was very handsome, when he had made himself over.
akâwâtêw êkwah awah kâ-kî-pakwâtât . Then she who had disliked him conceived a passion for him.
âtah kêtotâcih , namwâc ahpôh nôhtê-kitôtik . But even though she plied him with speech, he did not care to have her so much as speak to him.
êkwah awa kêsêyiniwit sîhkimik otânisah ôh ômisimâwa si-kakwêh-nipahât . Then the old man was urged by that elder daughter of his to try and kill him.

êkwah tâpwêh ,
ahag , nka-kakwê-nipahâw , itwêw awa kisêyiniw . And really, “Yes I shall try to kill him,” said the old man.

tântêh êtokê nikah-kîh-ohtinên miscikosah êh-miywâsikih ? itwêw awa oskinîkiw . “I wonder where I can get good little arrow-sticks?” said the youth. LB: In the ensuing episodes he is spoken of not by name, but as “that youth”.

êkwah ,
nk-êtohtahâw ninahâhkisîm , itwêw awa kisêyiniw . Then, “I shall take my son-in-law to such a place,” said the old man.
êkwah tâpwê itohtahêw êh-ministikôwiyik . And so he took him to an island.

ômis îtwêw awa kisêyiniw :
nipawâkan , êwakw âna kitasamitin ! itwêw . Thus spoke the old man: “My dream guardian, I feed you this man!” he said.
mayaw otati-sêskisihtay aw ôskinîkiw , ka-pê-môskîstâkot wâkayôsah , itôwahk kâ-wâpiskisicik . Hardly had the youth gone into the brush, when out came a bear at him, one of those who are white.
nika-nipahâw , cîw ômah êh-itêyihtaman ? itêw awa ; “‘I shall kill him,’ is that what you are thinking?” said he;
ayisk nîsta kôpawâkanimitin , itwêw . “For I, too, have you as my dream spirit,” he said.
tâpwêh nipahêw awa oskinîkiw . The youth really slew it.
ostikwâniyiw otinamwêw . He took its head.
kîwêhtatâw . He took it home with him.
âsiskawêw ôhi kisêyiniwa ; waskic nipîhk ati-pimohtêw . He outdistanced the old man; he walked along the surface of the water.
êh-kîwêt awa kisêyiniw , kâ-wâpahtahk wâkayôs ostikwân êh-akotêyik otiskwâhtêmihk ; When the old man went home, there he saw the bear's head hanging over the doorway;
mâka wiya kisêyiniw mawîhkâtêw opôwâkanah , êh-nipahimiht . the old man bewailed his dream guardian who had been slain.

âsay mina kîtahtawêh êh-ay-ayâcik , ômis îtwêw aw ôskinîkiw :
tântêh êtokê nkaw-ohtinâwak mîkwanak êh-miyosicik , nîpisisah kit-ôhc-ôsîhtâyân ? Presently, as they dwelt there, the youth spoke thus: “I wonder where I can get pretty feathers to make my arrows?”

seg.q: ôtêh ômah k-âsinîwacîwik , êkotê mistahi miyosiwak mîkwanak .
seg.gloss: “Over yonder amid the rocky cliffs, there the feathers are very fine.

p.seg: êkotê nik-êtohtahaw , itwêw awa kisêyiniw . I shall take him there,” said the old man.
tâpwê sipwêhtahêw êkotê isi . Really, he led him off to go there.
êkosi êkotê êh-takohtahât , piyêsiwa êh-owacistwaniyit . And so he brought him there where the thunderers had their nests.
hâw , nipawâkanitik , êwakw âna kitasamitinâwâw ! itêw . “Come, my dream guardians, I feed you this man!” he said to them.
êkosi isi-kîwêw . With that he turned to go home.
âsay mîna kahkiyaw nipahêw ôhih piyêsiwah . Again, he killed all those thunderers.

âsay mina ,
tântêh êtokê nkah-kih-ohtinên nîpisiy êh-miywâsik , kit-ôsihak ? Once more, “I wonder where I could get a good osier to make my bow?”

êkosi sâsay mînah kisêyiniw ,
nk-êtohtahâw itêh êh-miywâsiniyik nîpisiyah . Then again, the old man: “I shall take him where the willows are good.”
tâpwê itohtahêw . Really, he took him there.

âsay mina ,
ê , nipawâkan , hêwakoh kitasamitin ! itêw misi-kinêpikwah . Again, “Come my dream Guardian, this one I feed to you!” he said to a great serpent.
âsay mina awa oskinîkiw k-âsamimiht misi-kinêpikwah nipahêw . And again, the youth slew the Great Serpent to whom he was being fed.
ostikwâniyiw kîwêhtatâw . He took home its head.
âsay mina kisêyiniw nâway takohtêw . Again the old man was the second to arrive.
mawîhkâtêw mîna opawâkanah . He grieved over this dream spirit, too.
misi-kinêpik , nipawâkan ! itwêw . “Great Serpent, my dream guardian!” he cried.
êkwah namoya kîh-kiskêyayihtam tânis êkwah kita-kîh-isi-kawatimât ta-k-îsi-nipahât , ahpôh ta-kawatimât . Then he did not know how he could freeze him to death, to kill him, but by freezing him.

êkwah ômis îtwêw :
mâcîtân , ntêhkwâh ! itêw . So he said, “Let us hunt my nephew!” he said to him. LB's footnote on {ntêhkwâh}: Literally, “my sister's son (man speaking); my brother's son, my husband's sister's son (woman speaking),” often, as here, for {nahâhkis}: “son-in-law.” Similarly, {nisis}: “my mother's brother” for “my father-in-law” (See below), and {nisikos}: “my father's sister; my mother's brother's wife” for “my mother-in-law,” both of these being more specifically {manâcimâkan}: “person one dare not address, parent-in-law.” And {nahâhkan-iskwêw}: “daughter-in-law” is little used beside {nistim}: “my sister's daughter (man speaking); my brother's daughter, my husband's sister's daughter (woman speaking).”
tâpwê mâcîwak . Accordingly, they went hunting.
êh-tipiskâyik iyikohk , nipahêwak môswah . At night fall, no sooner, they killed a moose.

seg.gloss: “Pshaw! We shall have to sleep out!
We are soaked through to the bone!”

p.seg: kisopwâmisponiyiw . It was a warm-weather snowstorm.
pâsêtân kitayôwinisinawa ! itêw . “Let us dry our clothes,” he said to him.
tâpwê pâsamok , mitoni mistahi êh-pônahkik minahikoskâhk . So they dried them, feeding up a huge fire in a cedar-grove.
mayaw êh-kiskêyimât onahâhksîmah êh-nipâyit , otinamwêw otayôwinisiyiwa kâ-kîh-akotâyit . As soon as he knew that his son-in-law slept, he took the latter's clothes from where he had hung them.
kahkiyaw mêstihkasamwêw . He burned them all.

seg.gloss: “Hah, of course, for you are trying to kill me!

p.seg: -- itâp nika-môsôwin ! itwêw awa oskinîkiw . - So then I shall turn into a moose!” said the youth.
ntomêw , êh-ati-sipwêhtêt awa kisêyiniw kisinwah . As the old man went away, he called the cold.
tâpwê mistahi kisinâw . And really, it grew very cold.
ayisk ntômêw . For he had called it.
êkwah awah oskinîkiw kîwêw . Then that youth went home.
âsiskawêw osisah ; môsôwiw , êh-kîwêt . He outdistanced his uncle; he was in the form of a moose, as he went home.

êkwah ,
tânêhki ? itik wiwa . Then, “Why thus?” his wife asked him.

seg.gloss: “Because your father is trying to kill me, he burned up all my clothes.”

p.seg: têkohtêt awa kisêyiniw , apîwah onahâhkisîma . When the old man arrived, his son-in-law sat there.
kîhkâmik otânisa . His daughter upbraided him.
tânêhki mîna k-ô-mêstihkasamwat kitihkwatim otayôwinisah ? itik otânisa . “Why now did you burn up your nephew's clothes?” his daughter asked him.
hâ , êh-kîskwêhkwasiyân , itwêw awa kisêyiniw . “Oh dear, because I was walking in my sleep,” said the old man.
mahti pêyakwâw âsay mîna ! itêyihtam awa kisêyiniw . “Let me try once more!” thought the old man.
ninahâhkisîm , mahti mâcîtân ! itêw . “My son-in-law, let us hunt!” he said to him.
tâpwê mâcîwak . Accordingly, they went hunting.
namoya ta-kîh-kîwêyahk ! itêw sâsay mina . “We shall not be able to go home!” he said to him, again.
iyikohk êh-tipiskâyik , nipahêwak môswah . Not before nightfall they killed a moose.
kiyâm ka-kapêsinânaw , itwêw awa kisêyiniw ; “Let us camp,” said the old man;
kika-pâsênânaw kitayôwinisinawa , -- “We shall dry our clothes,”
kîhkîhk êkosi nka-kakwê-isi-nipahâw , êh-itêyihtahk awa kisêyiniw . for, “In spite of all, I shall try to kill him this way,” thought the old man.
êkwah akotâwak ê-kîh-pônahkik otayôwinisiwâwa . Then, after feeding up a fire, they hung up their clothes.
mayaw êh-nipâyit , awa oskinîkiw nihtinam kahkiyaw otayôwinisah . As soon as the other slept, the youth took down all of his own garments.
itah kâ-nipât astâw . He put them down where he slept.
êkwah kisêyiniw waniskâw . Then the old man got up.
pasakwâpiw , kontah ê-kîskwêhkwasîhkâsot . He squinted from under his eyelids, pretending to walk in his sleep.
wiya kêsêyiniwit kêhciwâk otayôwinisah kahkiyaw mêstihkasam . The old man himself burned up all his own clothes.
kêkway kâ-kîsitêk ? itêw . “What is that burning ?” he asked him.
ôhi niya k-âstêkih ntayôwinisah , itwêw awa ôskinîkiw ; “Here are my clothes, lying here,” said the youth;
kiy êtokê kêhciwâk kitayôwinisah kâ-pônaman , itêw ôhi kisêyiniwa ; “I daresay it is your own clothes you have put into the fire,” he said to the old man;

seg.q: ayisk êkosi kikîh-tôtawin ; nîsta mâka êkos îsi kik-êsi-nakatitin .
seg.gloss: “But seeing that you did it to me, I too shall now leave you, as you left me.”

p.seg: êhag ! itâp êtokê nka-môsôwin ! itwêw awa kisêyiniw . “Very well! I suppose I shall then turn into a moose!” said the old man.
nama kaskihtâw kita-môsôwit . But he did not succeed in turning into a moose.
ntomêw kisinwa awa wîsahkêcâhk . Wisahketchahk called the cold.
nipahêw ôhi kisêyiniwa . He killed the old man.
mâcikâ êkwah nôtokêsiw nêpahimiht onâpêma mistahi kisiwâsiw . Of course the old woman now was very angry, when her husband had been killed.

seg.gloss: “With this pounding stone four times I shall threaten you;

p.seg: êkotah kê-pakamahotân ! itwêw awa nôtokêsiw . then I shall strike you!” said the old woman.

nêwâw êh-nimahwât nâpiwa , otinamiyiwa ; ostikwân ohcih pîkwatahamiyiwa . When for the fourth time she held it over Napiw as if to strike, he took it; he smashed her head with it. LB's footnote to {nâpiwa}: The Blackfoot name.
mîna êwako nipahik . He killed her too.
êkosi êkwah awa kotak oskinîkiskwêw , mîna êwakoh nipahik . Thereupon that other young woman, her, too, he killed.
êkosi kahkiyaw êh-nipahikocik . So he killed them all.
macikah ayâwak êkotah wîsahkêcâhk . Of course Wisahketchahk and the other stayed there.

êkwah sipwêhtaw , êh-pêhtahk osîma kâ-kîh-mahîhkaniwiyit êh-nipahikoyit itâmi-nipîhk k-ôtaskiyit nanâtohk misi-pisiwah mina misi-kinêpikwah . Then he set out, for he heard that his little brother who had turned into a wolf had been slain by the various Great Panthers and Great Serpents that dwell under water. LB's footnote to {misi-pisiwah}: Special mention of lynxes is perhaps to be discounted, as a compliment to me, who am called {misi-pisiw}: “Great Lynx.”
êkwah mistahi kisiwâsiw . He was very angry.

seg.gloss: “I wonder what I shall do to go under the water!”

p.seg: kâ-wâpamât osîma , itah ê-kîh-nipahcikâsoyit , nipîhk mâna êh-ay-itâpi-t , êh-okimâwiyit kinosêwah otiskwâhtêmiyihk êh-akociniyit , mistahi pakwâtam . When he saw, as he always looked into the waters, his little brother, where he had been slain by them all, hanging over the doorway of the Chief Fish, he was filled with grief and hate.
kîtahtawêh itohtêw ; natawi-pimwêw ôhi k-ôkimâwiyit kinosêwah . Presently he went there; he went and shot with an arrow that Chief Fish.
papâmohtêw êkos îsi . Then he wandered about.
kîtahtawê kâ-wâpamât ayîkisah . Presently he saw a frog.
tânêhki ? itêw . “What is your errand?” he asked it.
hâ , nnatawi-nipiskêyân , itwêw awa ayîkis . “Why I am going to doctor by breathing,” said the frog.
tânisi kê-tôtaman , wîh-nipiskêyani ? itwêw awa wîsahkêcâhk . “What do you do, when you are breath-doctoring?” asked Wisahketchahk.
ê-kîh-wîhtamâkot , nipahêw ôhi . When it told him, he killed it.
naspitamôhisôw ; osîhisôw t-âyikisiwit . He turned himself into its form; he made himself to be a frog.
itohtêw êkwah ka-kanawêyihcikâsoyit kâ-mihkosiyit mahîhkaniwayânah . He went to where they kept the Red Wolfskin.

mayaw êh-pîhtokêt ,
tawîstâhk ! êwakw êkwa kâ-wîh-pê-pimâcihât ôhi wîsahkêcâhkwah kâkîh-pimwâyit , itâw . As soon as he entered, “Make way for this person! This is the one who has come to cure him whom Wisahketchahk has shot with an arrow,” was said of him.
tâpwê tawîstawâw . Accordingly, they made way for him.
êy-isi-tôtawât ôhi kâ-ntawi-nânapâcihât , êkwah tâpwê sôhkih kihcitânam ôma acosis . When he was treating him whom he had come to tend, then, truly, with a vim he thrust in that arrow.

seg.gloss: “What is that about a frog would be breathing on wounds!

p.seg: mistah ôma kikisiwâhinâwâw , nisîm êh-kîh-nipahâyêk ! itwêw wîsahkêcâhk . Rather you have angered me much by killing my little brother!” cried Wisahketchahk.
tapasîw êkos îsi . Then he fled.
kikisiwâhâwak maci-pisiskiwak ! itik manitôwa ; “You have enraged the evil beasts!” the Lord told him;

seg.q: kahkiyêw pâh-pêyak pisiskiwak ôtinah , nanâtohk kâ-papâmihâcik .
seg.gloss: Take one of every beast, and of all those who fly.

p.seg: êh-misâk ôsi osîhtâh , itik . Build a great canoe,” He told him.
êkospihk êsa maywês iskipêk ôma askiy , kahkiyaw kêkway êsah okîh-môtohtâwâw pisiskiwak . At that time, we are told, before this earth was flooded, all kinds of animals ate each other.
ahpôh paskwâwi-mostoswak kî-môwêwak ayîsiyiniwah , iyâtah-ayâyicih . Even the buffalo ate men, no matter where they were.
êkosi kiy-ispayiw êsah . That is the way things were.
kahkiyaw pâh-pêyak otinêw wîsahkêcâhk nâh-nîs ôhcih , pêyak nâpêw-âyisah , kiskisisah . Wisahketchahk took one of every kind, in pairs one male and one female.
kahkiyaw kâ-papâmihâyit , mîna ôtah askîhk misiwê kâ-ppâmohtêyit , kahkiyaw nâh-nîso ohci otinêw . Of all who fly and of all who walk about this earth, of each he took two.
êkosi osihtâw êh-misâyik ôsi . Then he built a great canoe.
êkosi kîh-wani-tipiskâyiw êsa . Then deep darkness came.
êkosi kahkiyaw atahkwak namoya ohc îhtakôwak . All the stars ceased to be.
misiwê kîh-iskipêyiw askiy , ê-kîh-kîsihtât êh-misâyik ôsi . Everywhere the earth was flooded, when he had finished the great canoe.
êkwah misiwê êy-iskipêyik , kahkiyaw asinîwaciyah êh-âyiwâkipêyikih , êkwah papâmahokôwak . Then, when the flood was everywhere, and all the mountains of rock were submerged, then they drifted about.
piyisk wî-nipahâhkatosôw . At last he nearly starved to death.
wîwa nipahâhkatosôyiwa . His wife starved to death.

êkwah ômisi kahkiyaw kêkwayah nipîhk k-ôtaskiyit mac-âyisah ê-wîh-kakwê-nipahikot , iyâtah-pêy-itohtêyici êh-nipahât , piyisk kahkiyaw kêkwayah kostik . Then, when all the creatures that dwell in the water, the evil beings, tried to kill him, when in vain they came there, and he slew them, then at last all creatures feared him.
êkwah kîtahtawê ksê-manitôwah kâ-pakicîtotâkot . Presently God descended to him.

ômis îtik :
kîspin êkâ kîh-kâhcitinamanê asiskiy , êkosi namoya wîhkâc kit-êhkipayiw ôma nipiy , itik . Thus He spoke to him: “If you cannot scrape up some earth, then never will these waters recede,” He told him.
misiwê êsah kiy-iskipêpan . the flood had covered all.
êkwah tânisi kê-tôtamân ? itêyihtam âta wiya . “Now how am I to do?” he thought, none the less.
ayisk kahkiyaw kîh-pôsihêw pisiskiwah . But he had all the beasts on his ship.
kîtahtawêh atotêw mâkwa , ta-kakwêh-otinamiyit asiskiy . Presently he bade the loon try to take up some soil.
pôtih namwâc kîh-kaskihtâyiwa . It turned out quite unable.
kîtahtawê mîna atotêw nikikwah . Then he presently he employed the otter.
namwâc kaskihtâyiwa . It was entirely unable to do it.
kahkiyaw tahtoh kâ-nihtâ-kôkiyit âta êh-atotât , namwâc kîh-kâhcitinamiyiwa asiskiy . Although he employed all, as many are good divers, they could not at all scrape up any earth.
kîtahtawê wacaskwah atotâw . Then in time he sent the muskrat. CHECK Misprint for atotêw ? YES HCW
nama mayaw mtonih takohtêyiwa . It was a long time coming back.
êwakoni apisîs kîh-kikamoyiw asiskiy . A little earth was sticking to it.
âsay mîna kîhtwâm sihkimêw . Again he bade it go.
âsay mîna pêtâyiwa . Again it brought some.
nêwâw sipwêhtisahwêw kita-nâtamiyit asiskiy . Four times he sent it off to fetch earth.
êkoyikohk ! itik manitôwa . “It is enough!” the Spirit told him.
êkotah ohci kî-miyikôwisiwak ayîsiyiniwak nêhiyawak , oskac askiy ôtah êh-ayâcik . Thus it was that the Indians were given this by the spirit powers, that first the they had an earth here.
êkosi kahkiyaw nipiy nama takon êkwa kahkiyaw . For then all the water ceased to be.
êkosi sipwêhtêw êkotah ohci wîsahkêcâhk . Then Wisahketchahk went away from here.
êkwah wiyasôwâtêw ayîsiyiniwah kit-ôwîcêwâkaniyit , ê-wîh-osihât manitôw . Then the Spirit decreed that he was to have man as a companion, and decided to create man.
asiskiy ohcih osihêw nîso ayîsiyiniwah . He made two human beings of earth.

êkwah maywês âpâhkawihât nâpêwa , ospikêkaniyiwa iskwêyânihk pêh-pêyak ohcih otinamwêw , êkwah k-âpâhkawihât . Then before He brought the men to life from each of them He took the lowest rib, and then He brought them to life.

nistam êh-pîkiskwêt ayîsiyiniw , ê-kîh-osihiht ,
nipiy ! kîh-itwêw êsah . When man first spoke, after being created, we are told that he said, “Water!”

kîhtwêm êh-pîkiskwêt ,
nimîciwin ! kîh-itwêw êsah . When he spoke again, we are told that he said “My food!”
kahkiyaw kêkway nama kêkway ohci kostikok . They were feared by all creatures, for no cause.
nâpêw kî-wihâw êsah . Then the man was named.

omihtikôs
k-îsi-wihâw nistam nâpêw . “Dug-out-canoe” the first man was named. LB's footnote to {omihtikôs}: The word is in Ojibwa form.
êkwah iskwêw . Then the woman.
nêwo kiy-âhâwak , pâh-pîtos êh-isi-wâhkôhtocik . Four of them dwelt there, being in different wise related, so as to make a family.
êkotah êkwah kî-sipwêhtisahwâw nistam kâhkâkiw , kahkiyaw askiy ê-wâsakamêt . Then from there the raven was first sent out to make a circuit of the earth.
pôtih ncawâc kîh-asênâw . In the outcome he was needs rejected. LB's footnote: Or read {kîh-asêhâw}: “he flew back.”
êkwah kihiw kî-sipwêhtisahwâw . Then the eagle was sent out.
êkotah ohcih nama wîhkâc êsah kîh-nipiwak ayîsiyiniwak . In the time that began then, people never died.
pêyâhtik kîh-kâmwâcih-pimâtisiwak , piyisk êh-atih-mihcêticik . They lived quietly and undisturbed, until at last they came to be many.
kî-miskamwak tânisi êh-isi-pimâcihocik . They found how to keep themselves alive.
êkotah ohci ka-pêw-ohpikihitot nêhiyaw , ayîsiyiniw . From that time to this in successive generations has come the Cree, the Indian.
nanâtohk ayîsiyiniw kahkiyaw ninisitohtên ôma kâ-ntawêyihtâkwahk âcimôwin . Of all the different peoples I understand this story which is desired.

nêhiyaw tânisi êy-isi-pimâtisit , ê-kîh-pêy-isih-ohpikihitocik nêhiyawak , kahkiyaw nikiskêyihtên . Of how the Cree lived, as the Cree have come down through the generations to this time, all of this I know.

mîna wâpiski-wiyâs ôtah kâ-pêh-takohtatât ayamihâwin , kahkiyaw min êôkô nikiskêyihtên , tânisi êh-pêh-isih-wîhcikâtêyik . And of the Christian worship which the white man has brought here with him, of this, too, I know all, of how it has been announced to this time.
ôhcitaw nitâtayôhkâtên nistam ayîsiyiniw , tânisi ê-kîh-isih-osîhcikâsot nêhiyaw . I have chosen to tell the sacred story of how the first man was created, the Indian.

mâskôc êkotôwahk kâ-ntawêyihcikâtêk , mâskôc êh-nohtê-kiskêyihtamihk nêhiyaw opimâtisiwin , êy-itêyihtamân , k-ôh-isih-âtayôhkêyân . Because I have thought that doubtless this is what is desired, that doubtless people wish to know of the life of the Indian, that is why I tell this sacred story.

nîswâw mitâtahtomitanaw askiy ê-kîh-ispayik , êkospihk êsa okî-nipahikwah wâkayôsah êwakoh nistam ayîsiyiniw , êsah êh-kîh-nipit . When twice a hundred years had gone by, at that time, this first man was killed by a bear, and so he died.

êwakoh niyanân kâ-nêhiyawiyâhk ônipiwah ocâhcâhkoyiwah ta-kanawêyimât kîh-itasôwâtik êsa manitôwa . Then, we are told, he was assigned by the Spirit to care for the souls of the dead of us who are Indians.
matwân_cî kêyâpic êkosi ispayiw ; namoya nika-kîh-itwân . I question if it is still so; I cannot say.
ayisk osâm ninisiwanâcihisonân . For too greatly we are destroying ourselves.
kih-kitahamôwâw ayîsiyiniw êkâ kit-ayamihât ; êwakoh ohci kâh-itwêyân . The Indian was forbidden to practise the Christian Religion; that is what I mean.

seg.q: nêhiyaw kây-isiyîhkâsot pikoh kây-itak : êkâyah ayamihâhkan ! namoya kiya kâ-miyitân .
seg.gloss: “I say this only to him who is called Indian: thou shalt not worship in Christian wise! Not to thee do I give this.

p.seg: ntawâsimisah ohcitaw nimiyâw wâpiski-wiyâs , kita-kakwâtakihot , wiya ê-kîh-nipahât ntawâsimisah , kîh-itwêw êsah manitôw . I give my son to the white man, that he may suffer for having slain my Son,” said the Lord.
êkoykikohk êyakôw pêyak pîkiskwêwin . So much for this discourse.
